docs.title: List of Biochemistry Topics
docs.text: Explore the foundational concepts and techniques in Biochemistry. Click on a topic to dive deeper.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
1. The Molecular Design of Life

    • Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

  2. Water Chemistry and pH

    • Properties of water, pH scales, buffering systems.

  3. Amino Acids

    • Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

  4. Proteins: Structure and Folding

    • Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

  5. Protein Purification Techniques

    • Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

  6. Enzymes and Thermodynamics

    • Enzyme classifications, kinetics, thermodynamic principles.

  7. Enzyme Regulation

    • Enzyme inhibition, covalent modifications, ligand-protein interactions.

  8. Carbohydrates

    • Carbohydrate structure, glycosidic bonds, biological roles.

  9. Nucleic Acids

    • Nucleotide structure, DNA/RNA functions, biotechnology applications.

docs.title: Types of Chemical Bonds
docs.text:
Download the bbq-MC-bond_types-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Types of Chemical Bonds"

Which one of the following types of chemical bonds correspond to the example 'C - C (in benzene, C6H6)'.

  • A. hydrogen bond
  • B. ionic bond
  • C. non-polar covalent bond
  • D. polar covalent bond
Check Answer

"Click to show example problem on Types of Macromolecules"

Which one of the following types of macromolecules correspond to the macromolecule 'oligosaccharides'.

Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas
docs.text:
Download the bbq-which_hydrophobic-simple-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas" Based on their molecular formula, which one of the following compounds is most likely hydrophobic?
  • A. ethanol, CH3CH2OH 
  • B. butane, CH3CH2CH2CH3
  • C. erythrose, C4H8O4
  • D. methanol, CH3OH 
  • E. glycine, NH2CH2COOH 
Check Answer

docs.title: Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures
docs.text:
Download the bbq-which_macromolecule-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures" Guide to Identifying the Chemical Structures of Macromolecules Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • Should have about the same number of oxygens as carbons.
  • Look for hydroxyl groups (–OH) attached to the carbon atoms.
  • Carbonyl groups (C=O) are often present as well.
  • Look for the base unit of CH2O.
  • Larger carbohydrates will form hexagon or pentagon ring-like structures.
Lipids (fatty acids)
  • Contain mostly carbon and hydrogen.
  • Very few oxygens and often no nitrogens.
  • Fats and oils will have carboxyl groups (–COOH) and ester bonds
  • Look for long chains or ring structures of only carbon and hydrogen.
  • Steroids have four interconnected carbon rings.
Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • Always have a nitrogen/amino group (–NH2 or –NH3+)
  • Always have a carboxyl group (–COOH or –COO-)
  • Identify the central Cα (alpha-carbon) attached to an amino group and a carboxyl group
  • Larger protein macromolecules will have a characteristic peptide bond (C–N)
  • Try to identify common side chains (R groups).
Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
  • Must have a nucleobase, rings containing carbon and nitrogen.
  • Larger nucleic acids will have a sugar backbone and phosphate groups.
Phosphate groups (–PO42-)
  • Found in all of the macromolecule types.
  • It is best to ignore them to not let them confuse you.
  • The breakdown of carbohydrates involves add phosphates.
  • Membrane lipids have phosphate head groups.
  • Many proteins are phosphorylated for regulatory purposes.
  • DNA has a phosphate backbone.

Molecule Information Full name Pseudouridine Molecular formula C9 H12 N2 O6 Molecular weight 244.20 g/mol Image link link to static image Partition coefficient -2.8 logP C/(O+N) ratio 1.1 Which one of the four main types of macromolecules is represented by the chemical structure of Pseudouridine shown above?
  • A. Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • B. Lipids (fatty acids)
  • C. Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • D. Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 2: Water Chemistry and pH
docs.text: Properties of water, pH scales, buffering systems.

docs.title: Optimal Buffering Range using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-optimal_buffering_range-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Optimal Buffering Range using pKa"

Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Which one of the following pH values falls outside the optimal buffering rangeof Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid?

  • A. pH 1.9
  • B. pH 2.9
  • C. pH 5.6
  • D. pH 9.0
  • E. pH 9.3
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-pKa_buffer_state-2_protons-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa"

Fumaric acid and its conjugate base, fumarate, is produced by human skin when exposed to sunlight and is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.Fumaric acid is diprotic with pKa values of 3.03 and 4.44.Fumaric acid has three possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 5.5?

  • A. (COO)CH=CH(COO)2-
  • B. (COOH)CH=CH(COO)-
  • C. (COOH)CH=CH(COOH)
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-pKa_buffer_state-3_protons-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa"

Citric acid and its conjugate base, citrate, is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.Citric acid is triprotic with pKa values of 3.13, 4.76, and 6.39.Citric acid has four possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 2.0?

  • A. HOC3H4(COOH)3
  • B. HOC3H4(COOH)2(COO)-
  • C. HOC3H4(COOH)(COO)22-
  • D. HOC3H4(COO)33-
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-pKa_buffer_state-4_protons-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa"

Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid has five possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 5.0?

  • A. C10H12N2O84-
  • B. C10H13N2O83-
  • C. C10H14N2O82-
  • D. C10H15N2O8-
  • E. C10H16N2O8
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 3: Amino Acids
docs.text: Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

docs.title: Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure
docs.text:
Download the bbq-2_amino_acids-polypeptide_mc_sequence-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure" peptide_4529

A dipeptide is made up of two (2) amino acids. The figure above shows one such dipeptide with an unknown sequence. Your task is to find out the two (2) letter sequence of this dipeptide.Here is a step-by-step guide to help you answer the question:

  1. Consult an amino acid guide for reference. You can find a PDF guide on Blackboard under "Exam and Quiz" in the "Old Exams" section, with the filename bchm_exam-help_sheet.pdf, or search online for a visual guide that shows all 20 amino acids with their single-letter codes.
  2. Identify the amino-terminal end, represented as NH3+ and highlighted in bright green. Distinguish between the general nitrogens in amino acid backbones (denoted as NH) and the nitrogen in amino acid side chains.
  3. The one (1) peptide bonds connecting the two (2) amino acids are highlighted in bright green, making it easier to distinguish the two (2) amino acids.
  4. Examine the side chain for each of the two (2) amino acids to determine their single-letter amino acid code.
  5. List the single-letter amino acid codes in the amino to carboxyl (N→C) direction. This is the standard method for writing peptide sequences.

Select the correct peptide sequence from the options below:

  • A. QW 
  • B. FW 
  • C. MC 
  • D. QC 
  • E. YH 
Check Answer

  • A. arginine
  • B. asparagine
  • C. methionine
  • D. threonine
  • E. valine

docs.title: Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures
docs.text:
Download the bbq-alpha_helix_h-bonds-MC-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures"

The α-helix is a right-handed coil in which each backbone N–H group forms a hydrogen bond with the C=O group of an amino acid located a few residues away. The regular pattern of hydrogen bonding stabilizes the helix, preventing it from unraveling.In a long α-helix, amino acid number 7 would form a hydrogen bond with which two other amino acids?Select the correct pair of amino acids below.

  • A. amino acids 5 and 9 (a residue shift of 2 positions) 
  • B. amino acids 4 and 10 (a residue shift of 3 positions) 
  • C. amino acids 3 and 11 (a residue shift of 4 positions) 
  • D. amino acids 2 and 12 (a residue shift of 5 positions) 
  • E. amino acids 1 and 13 (a residue shift of 6 positions) 
Check Answer

docs.title: Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains
docs.text:
Download the bbq-ionic_bond_amino_acids-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains" Based on the chemical properties of amino acid side chains, which pair of amino acids listed below can form an ionic bond between their side chains?
  • A. Arginine and Glutamate 
  • B. Glycine and Lysine 
  • C. Alanine and Cysteine 
  • D. Tryptophan and Phenylalanine 
  • E. Methionine and Aspartate 
Check Answer

docs.title: Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH
docs.text:
Download the bbq-isoelectric_one_protein-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH" Isoelectric Point Problem Protein Name isoelectric point (pI) molecular weight Aldolase (Aldo) 8.5 47.5

The protein in the table (above) is placed in a buffer solution with a pH of 9.5.What is the correct net charge on the Aldo protein at pH of 9.5?

  • A. The protein will have a net positive (+) charge. 
  • B. The protein will have a net negative (–) charge. 
  • C. The protein will have a net neutral (0) charge. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point
docs.text:
Download the bbq-isoelectric_two_proteins-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point" Isoelectric Point Problem

A mixture of two proteins are to be separated by isoelectric focusing.

ProteinName IsoelectricPoint (pI) MolecularWeight Histone (His) 10.8 15.0 Elastase II (Ela) 8.5 26.5

Both protein samples are placed into a gel with a constant pH of 7.5. The gel is then placed into an electric field.In which direction will each protein in the table migrate at pH 7.5?

  • A. Both His and Ela will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • B. Both His and Ela will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
  • C. His will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal Ela will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • D. His will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal Ela will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
Check Answer

docs.title: Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration
docs.text:
Download the bbq-protein_gel_migration-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration" Gel Migration Problem

In this task, data from an SDS-PAGE experiment, where proteins are separated based on molecular weight, is provided. The gel results table below shows some standard proteins with known molecular weights and one unknown protein.

Protein Name MolecularWeight (kDa) MigrationDistance (cm) Histone (His) 15.0 3.33 Myelin Basic Protein (MBP) 18.0 3.19 Chymotrypsin (Chy) 25.0 2.92 Pepsin (Pep) 34.5 2.67 Enolase (Eno) 42.5 2.50 Neuraminidase (Neu) 50.0 2.37 Catalase (Cat) 65.5 2.15 Unknown ? 2.45 Estimate the molecular weight of the unknown protein by comparing its gel migration distance with those of the standards.
  • A. 17 kDa 
  • B. 21 kDa 
  • C. 31 kDa 
  • D. 40 kDa 
  • E. 45 kDa 
Check Answer

docs.title: Energy Terms and Their Categories
docs.text:
Download the bbq-MC-energy_terms-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Energy Terms and Their Categories"

Which one of the following energy requirement categories correspond to the energy term 'non-spontaneous'.

  • A. releases energy
  • B. requires energy input
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions
docs.text:
Download the bbq-chemical_reactions-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE regarding chemical reactions?

  • A. Chemical reactions are always either exothermic or endothermic. 
  • B. Chemical reactions always involve the forming and breaking of chemical bonds 
  • C. Chemical reactions always involve a change in the chemical composition of substances. 
  • D. For chemical reactions to occur, the chemical formulas of both the reactant and the product cannot be the same. 
  • E. The rate of a chemical reactions depend on temperature, pressure, and the presence of catalysts. 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)
docs.text:
Download the bbq-gibbs_free_energy_equation-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE concerning the Gibbs free energy, ΔG = ΔH – TΔS?

  • A. enthalpy is associated with the amount of heat exchanged with the environment 
  • B. When ΔG < 0 the reaction is calledspontaneous
  • C. Tis the temperature in degrees Kelvin
  • D. ΔG is the change in enthalpy
  • E. When ΔG = 0 the reaction has reached equilibrium 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics
docs.text:
Download the bbq-thermodynamics-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is TRUE of thermodynamics and kinetics?

  • A. A reaction is spontaneous if the standard change in free energy (ΔG°′) is negative. 
  • B. Enzymes change the standard Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°′) of a reaction. 
  • C. Kinetics is determined by a combination of enthalpy and entropy. 
  • D. The second law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of a closed system always decreases. 
  • E. Thermodynamics determines the rate of a reaction. 
Check Answer
